items.content_html:
Watched: 28 Years Later: The Bone Temple ðŸŽ¬

Very different vibe for this instalment of the trilogy, with more emphasis on the evil of the non-infected but also, crucially, the humanity and compassion that still exists.

Jack Oâ€™Connell is outstanding as Sir Lord Jimmy Crystal. The Jimmy Savile stuff isnâ€™t overplayed and not knowing anything about him â€“ which I expect would apply to a fair majority of a US/non-British audience â€“ doesnâ€™t get in the way of the story.

Gory in parts â€“ and this may be weird to say given this is technically a horror film â€“ but I think unnecessarily so. If it had been toned down I donâ€™t think the film would have suffered but I get why itâ€™s there.

Very good film. Canâ€™t wait for the third and final instalment, given how itâ€™s set up at the end.
items.content_text:

Very different vibe for this instalment of the trilogy, with more emphasis on the evil of the non-infected but also, crucially, the humanity and compassion that still exists.

Jack Oâ€™Connell is outstanding as Sir Lord Jimmy Crystal. The Jimmy Savile stuff isnâ€™t overplayed and not knowing anything about him â€“ which I expect would apply to a fair majority of a US/non-British audience â€“ doesnâ€™t get in the way of the story.

Gory in parts â€“ and this may be weird to say given this is technically a horror film â€“ but I think unnecessarily so. If it had been toned down I donâ€™t think the film would have suffered but I get why itâ€™s there.

Very good film. Canâ€™t wait for the third and final instalment, given how itâ€™s set up at the end.

items.title: Hamnet ðŸŽ¬ â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†
items.content_html:
Watched: Hamnet ðŸŽ¬

First things first: Paul Mescal and Jessie Buckley are brilliant in Hamnet, it’s well worth the two hours' run time and keeps you engaged throughout, and the sound design and photography is amazing.

However… based on all the articles and previews I read, I was expecting to be sobbing and ugly crying throughout the film, but it wasn’t as weepy as I was expecting. I’m someone who has a good cry at films and books and there were moments when tears fell during Hamnet, but not torrents like I was expecting. That could be a good or bad thing depending on your point of view. I’m kind of aligned with Mark Kermode’s review, I suppose, though I disagree with what he said about being aware of being manipulated into feeling overcome with emotion.

Objectively a great film, but doesn’t get the full five stars from me, mainly because I’m reserving five stars for films I would happily watch again and again, like Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.
items.content_text:
Watched: [Hamnet](https://www.themoviedb.org/movie/858024) ðŸŽ¬

First things first: Paul Mescal and Jessie Buckley are brilliant in Hamnet, it's well worth the two hours' run time and keeps you engaged throughout, and the sound design and photography is amazing.

However... based on all the articles and previews I read, I was expecting to be sobbing and ugly crying throughout the film, but it wasn't as weepy as I was expecting. I'm someone who has a good cry at films and books and there were moments when tears fell during Hamnet, but not torrents like I was expecting. That could be a good or bad thing depending on your point of view. I'm kind of aligned with [Mark Kermode's review](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mGuG4iG0zFE), I suppose, though I disagree with what he said about being aware of being manipulated into feeling overcome with emotion.

Objectively a great film, but doesn't get the full five stars from me, mainly because I'm reserving five stars for films I would happily watch again and again, like [Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind](https://kennethyau.net/2026/01/08/eternal-sunshine-of-the-spotless.html).

items.title: Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind ðŸŽ¬ â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
items.content_html:
Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind

Rewatched for the first time in ages and even better than I remembered it, which is saying something since Iâ€™ve always loved this film.

The ending was longer than I remembered. For some reason, I thought the film ended with Joel and Clementine meeting on the train â€“ this does not count as a spoiler, even if you ignore the film being more than 20 years old â€“ but I guess thereâ€™s a nice irony to my memory of the film being imperfect!
items.content_text:
[Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind](https://www.themoviedb.org/movie/38-eternal-sunshine-of-the-spotless-mind)

Rewatched for the first time in ages and even better than I remembered it, which is saying something since Iâ€™ve always loved this film.

The ending was longer than I remembered. For some reason, I thought the film ended with Joel and Clementine meeting on the train â€“ this does not count as a spoiler, even if you ignore the film being more than 20 years old â€“ but I guess thereâ€™s a nice irony to my memory of the film being imperfect!

items.title: Song Sung Blue ðŸŽ¬ â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†
items.content_html:
Song Sung Blue ðŸŽ¬

Another solid 4 stars from me, following on from yesterday’s 4 star for Marty Supreme.

Very different film to Marty Supreme in that it’s way more conventional and feel-good while â€“ mild spoiler alert â€“ not being completely feel-good.

But also similar in being biopics. That said, Marty Supreme, while ostensibly a biopic and based on an actual person, is clearly taking liberties with the story and is more fiction than fact. If I’m reading correctly, the story in Song Sung Blue is what actually went down, which is amazing to me, having seen the film.

Anyway, while not quite Barbenheimer, the 24-hour double bill of Marty Supreme and Song Sung Blue was a nice contrast of intellectual slapstick comedy and old-fashioned unashamed entertainment squarely aimed at your heart and tear ducts.

Another solid 4 stars from me, following on from yesterday's 4 star for [Marty Supreme](https://kennethyau.net/2026/01/01/marty-supreme.html).

Very different film to Marty Supreme in that it's way more conventional and feel-good while â€“ mild spoiler alert â€“ not being completely feel-good.

But also similar in being biopics. That said, Marty Supreme, while ostensibly a biopic and based on an actual person, is clearly taking liberties with the story and is more fiction than fact. If I'm reading correctly, the story in Song Sung Blue is what actually went down, which is amazing to me, having seen the film.

Anyway, while not quite Barbenheimer, the 24-hour double bill of Marty Supreme and Song Sung Blue was a nice contrast of intellectual slapstick comedy and old-fashioned unashamed entertainment squarely aimed at your heart and tear ducts.

items.title: Marty Supreme ðŸŽ¬ â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†
items.content_html:
Watched: Marty Supreme

A solid 4 stars from me. For the first act, I was utterly gripped and enchanted and thought this was heading easily for a 5-star rating, but I felt it sagged a bit in the second act and could have done with a bit of editing. There’s one particular strand of the story I believe could have been excised without losing anything. That said, it picked up marvellously in the third act.

TimothÃ©e Chalamet should definitely be in the running for an Oscar for this though I believe he will/should (deservedly) miss out to Michael B Jordan, for the latter’s performance in Sinners.
items.content_text:

A solid 4 stars from me. For the first act, I was utterly gripped and enchanted and thought this was heading easily for a 5-star rating, but I felt it sagged a bit in the second act and could have done with a bit of editing. There's one particular strand of the story I believe could have been excised without losing anything. That said, it picked up marvellously in the third act.

TimothÃ©e Chalamet should definitely be in the running for an Oscar for this though I believe he will/should (deservedly) miss out to Michael B Jordan, for the latter's performance in Sinners.

items.content_html:
Hello, world.

It’s a new year, so of course I’m going to start a new blog.

Lesson learned from previous attempts: not to overthink the first post; just lance that boil with a quick post like this one, and crack on.
items.content_text:

Lesson learned from previous attempts: not to overthink the first post; just lance that boil with a quick post like this one, and crack on.
